div.p:

To the preceding it is continued thus because after the Master showed that in the divine there is true generation, now in this distinction he puts a multitude of properties signifying its perfection. Et this is divided into three parts because in the first place the Master makes determinations about the eternal being of God, in the second place about his unchangeability, in the third place about his simplicity. The second begins at
deus in solius essentia Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 2 (I, 97, ll.2). , the third at
eademque Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 3 (I, 98, ll. 20). . The first is in three parts, for in the first place he shows how this name being or essence is proper to God, in the second place from what has been said is introduces a doubt, and in the third place he responds to it. The second begins at
hic diligenter Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 1 (I, 95, ll. 21-22). . The third begins at
illud ergo quod Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 1 (I, 96, ll. 20). . The second principal part is undivided, but the third is divided into two parts because in the first place the Master shows the simplicity of the divine nature through comparison and external relations, in the second place through internal relation. The second begins at
hic diligenter

. And this is the division of the present distinction.

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether the first cause of a producibile being alone is simple, necessary, and unchangeable or invariable?

div.head: Rationes principales
div.p: That not, there is some creature that is indivisibly simple, therefore etc. The antecedent is proved then because to every specific grade of some thing there corresponds a punctual or indivisible being. This is clear because, whenever something grade is added or subtracted no matter how small, the thing does not remain in the same species, therefore such a thing is indivisible.

In the second place, there something below the first cause that is necessary, therefore. The antecedent is clear because through
the Holy Doctor Contra Gentiles, book two, chapter 29 , where from what has been said
therefore that in which there is not matter, or, if there is, there is not potentaility for another form, does not have the potency for non being, therefore such things are absolutely necessary
Aquinas, Summa contra gentiles, II, c. 29 (13, 335). . But it is certain that an neither an angel nor a a soul has matter, therefore. This is confirmed because an angel and a soul do not have within them a principle leading them to non being, therefore they have no potency for non being, therefore they are necessary.

In the third place, in the first cause there is an absolute modal distinction and a conceptual or virtual distinction, therefore. The antecedent for the first part is from
James of Viterbo Iacobus de Viterbo, XXX
and for the second part is from
Alphonsus, distinction eight of book one, article two, conclusion four Alphonsus Toletanus Vargas, I, d. 8, a. 1, conc. 4 . The consequences is clear because any such distinction is repugnant to the highest simplicity.

In opposition is the opinion of the
Master in this distinction Lombardus, Sent. I, d.8, c. 3 (I, 98) et 6, (I, 100). . Again the
Apostle in I Timothy 6
says says that
God alone has immortality I Timotheum 6:16 . Again Augustine III De Trinitate says
God alone does not change and is not able to change Augustinus, De Trinitate, III, XXX .

div.head: First conclusion
div.p: The first conclusion: it is as necessary that the first cause is as it is that a creature is able to be. This is proved because inasmuch as it is necessary that God is God and is omnipotent, by as much necessity he is externally productive, and by as much necessity is something external able to be produced and is able to have being, therefore etc. This is confirmed because, if the first cause were not able to produce anything outside itself, it would seem that from the fact that something is producible it would be produced, but this is impossible. Nor does this seem to be a problem because it would still be able to corrupt this whole and then recreate it, therefore.

First corollary: thought it is not the case that a creature is not able not to be, nevertheless if the first cause were to act outside itself through the mode of nature, then it would be necessary for some producible thing to be. The first part is clear because some created thing is contingently produced by and in conserved in its being. The second part is clear because, if one thing were produced and not another thing, then either this would be because it would were determined that this thing be produced and not the other, and not this because this is to produce freely since one is equally as possible as the other, or this would be because one thing would be able to be produced and not the other, but this is not the case because then it would be producible and not producibile.

Second corollary: if the first cause were to act outside itself necessarily and naturally, all producibile and corruptibile things would be produced and corrupted at the same time and equally. This is clear because if a fire itself were able to produce b heat and corrupt b heat, it would produce and corrupt at the same time. Therefore, since the first cause alone is able with another it is able in the genus of an efficient cause, the proposed follows that if it were to act naturally, etc.

Third corollary: it is not stand that the first cause is productive of every producible creature and to this to act outside of itself from the necessity of nature. This is clear to this that to produce naturally, it would follows that all producible things are produced and corrupted at the same time and equally. But this implies a contradiction, therefore.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
The second conclusion: though only three supposites are distinguished in the one super simple essence, nevertheless this is not properly called diversity or difference. The first part is clear through faith because there is one Father, another Son, and another Holy Spirit, therefore only three supposites are distinguished in the divine essence. This is confirmed because a distinction or difference is nothing, therefore the should not be put in God. This is clear because whatever is in God is something. The antecedent is clear because if only God and man were to exists and nothing else, God and man would still be different, therefore distinction or difference are nothing something or somethings. For this
conclusion there is the reasoning
Augustine VI De Trinitate, chapter 4, de magnis Augustinus, De Trinitate, VI, c. 4
and
chapter 14, de parvis Augustinus, De Trinitate, VI, c. 14 . From the second part of the conclusion, it follows that though it would be said truly and properly that some things are distinguished in reality, and in intention, and in reason, nevertheless it is not properly said that this distinct is intentional, real, or of reason. This is clear because a distinction is nothing, therefore it is not. The consequence is clear because what is absolutely nothing does not exists

First corollary: every perfection which God really is some perfection of God formally. This is clear because, if the divine perfections in some mode differed or were different, it would follow that the divine supposites would not differ only in the divine essence. The consequence is clear in
the first part of the second conclusion Vide supra .

Second corollary: that just among divine perfections there is no formal distinction, so also are a distinction of reason or modal distinction repugnant to them Or thus, just as it does not stand that the divine perfections are distinguished formally, so it is also repugnant for them to be distinguished by reason or formally. This is clear because otherwise in them there would not be the highest simplicity and indifference.

Third corollary: just as it is repugnant that there are a plurality of Gods, so it is repugnant that there are a formal diversity of perfections in God. This is clear because, if such a plurality of formalities in God were possible, it follows that there is something which is absolutely formally God which is not every God. Again, it would follow that something would be God really which is merely contingent, but this is as repugnant as it is that there are many gods, therefore. The first consequence is proved because if divine justice is God formally, then the divine wisdom, if it is formally not justice, then it will not be God formally. The second consequence is clear because the fact that God wants to beatify Peter is really God, and nevertheless by positing formalities of this type God is contingently.

These three corollaries seem to be from the mind of Anselm in the Monologion chapter 17 who says
whatever is said essentially about the highest essence, thus this is in one consideration essentially one. For since some man is said to be a body, rational, and man, he is not in any mode or consideration said to be three things. Thus truly the highest divine essence is in no way said in such a way that it is not this same thing according to consideration and according to another Anselmus, Monologion, 17, (I, 31, ll. 25-32) . From this these corollary seem to be clear.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p:
Third conclusion: just as the first cause alone has every perfection absolutely and is including itself, so also is it formally and completely lacking any kind of compositions and excluding from itself. The first part is proved because according to Anselm God is
that which nothing greater or better is able to be thought Anselmus, Proslogion 3 (I, 103, ll. 1-2) . The second part is because simplicity should be placed before composition according to
Augustine De quantitate animae, chapter 12 Augustinus, De quantitate, XXX , ergo, But the first cause alone is of the highest simplicity. This is clear indivisibility, immutability, and per se actuality belong to the ratio of simplicity, but these things suit God alone and are not able to be found in a creature.

The first corollary: any species either of a given or giveable form are perfectly confluibile into a superior form or species. This is clear because no such species is unchangeable in its being, therefore God is able to make it that flow together in a unified way into something superior.

The second corollary: it is not the case that some individual depends on a first cause and unitively contains every degree of perfection. This is clear because then such an individual would not be able flow unitively with another individual into a superior species or into some more perfect individual.

The third corollary: it is not the case for some individual that it is repugnant that some dependent created being is not able to be subjectively under some accident and that it is repugnant that this created thing truly is able to unitively contain every grade of simplicity. This is clear because non individual of any given
or giveable species is able to be so simple that it is not able to be the subject of an elicited act or the subject of some habit infused by God, therefore. The antecedent is clear because simplicity of this type suits God alone. From what has been said the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

div.head: Objections
div.p: Against the first conclusion and its corollaries: something other than God is necessary, therefore. The antecedent is proved because the divine perfection goes out to what is produced similar to itself to the degree that is not repugnant to the creature. But to be necessary is not repugnant to a creature, therefore the divine goodness produces the creatures in this way. The major premise is known. The minor premise is clear because, if it were repugnant to the creature to be necessary, then it would seem to be by virtue of the fact that it comes from another. But this is not the case because the Son has his being from another, and nevertheless it does not have this being contingently, therefore.

In the second place, if an angel or the soul were able not to be, then this would be because God withdrew his influence from them. But this is impossible because this would mean his goodness had changed, therefore such things are not able to be.

In the third place: substances separated from matter do not have a passive potency for privation or corruption, therefore they are not able not to be. The consequence holds since matter is the ratio of maintenance and corruption in creatures. These are the arguments of the Holy Doctor, in the place it was noted earlier at the beginning of the question.

In the fourth place: because either for something to be necessary it corresponds precisely either that it is punctual or quantitive. If the first, then it is not of immense perfection. If the second, then it is able to be imagined in this species that there is a greater and lesser necessity, since for every thing that has quantity there is able to be given something less, so it is possible to give to this necessity a lesser quantity, and thus there will be many types of necessity.

In the fifth place: if the entire line of producbile things were contingent with respect to being and non being, it follows that the whole would be able to be put completely into being. The consequent is false through what has been said because the first cause would not be able to act outside itself. The consequence is clear because the whole is able not to be as
the first corollary Vide supra
says.

In the sixth place: no individual of an inferior species is able to contain the total perfection of its species, therefore it is necessary that one thing is not able to contain the total breadth of necessity, therefore there is not only one thing in that species. The antecedent is clear through the
second corollary of the third conclusion Vide supra , and the consequences are clear. This is confirmed because to be, as the proposition man is an animal signified, is necessary being, therefore there are many necessary beings. The consequence holds because this is not God..

Again, to this proposition nothing is, a contradiction does not follow, there this is able to be true, therefore nothing is necessary to be necessary. The consequences holds, and the antecedent is proved because to no negative does an affirmative follow, therefore neither does some contradiction because every contradiction is composed from an affirmative and negative or at least includes one.

Against the second conclusion: in the first place it is argued the authority the Damascene, in book one, chapter three, where he says
Whatever we say about God affirmatively does not show his nature but those things, which are about his nature. For if you say he is good, if just, and if wise, and anything else, you do not speak his nature.
Ioannes Damescenus, I, c. 4, (PG 94.799BC); Burgundionis versio 4,5, p. 21, 41-45)

Against the first corollary: if God were immensely simple, he would be so either divisibly or indivisibly. Not the first because then he would have parts. Not the second because then he alone through his indivisibility would stand apart from nothing, and thus the divine essence would be infinitely less distant from an angel than any creature, which is false.

In the second place, wisdom in common is not justice in common, therefore infinite wisdom is not infinite justice. The consequence holds because infinity does not destroy the proper ratio of something, as it seems.

Against the second corollary: those things which are not synonymous signify diverse things or the same thing by diverse reasons. But goodness, and justice, mercy, and eternity are not synonymous in God, therefore. But they do not
signify diverse things, therefore by diverse modes. Therefore in God there is a modal distinction as stated by
James of Viterbo, Quodlibet three, question seven Iacobus de Viterbio, Quodlibet III, q. 7, 2, XXX .

In the second place it follows that willing divine would be formally and an intellective divine and the conversely. The consequent is false because then, whatever the object may be, one would be the object of the other. This mode is false because God understands the evil of guilt which he nevertheless in no way wishes.

Third: that which necessitates the intellect to essentially distinct acts is distinguished according to reason or conceptually. But the divine perfections necessitate the intellect to essentially distinct acts, therefore divine perfections of this type are distinct conceptually or virtually. The major is clear where one thing necessitates to essentially distinct acts this makes the same thing that really distinct diverse things would make. The minor is clear because divine wisdom necessitates the intellect to the concept of wisdom and goodness to the concept of goodness, and such concepts are really and essential distinct, therefore, ergo. Alphonsus.

In the fourth place against the third corollary: non justice is not repugnant to wisdom as such, therefore wisdom in some mode is the same as justice. But another god is not repugnant to divine wisdom, therefore.
Against the third conclusion is another proposition in De causis in which it is said that intelligence is a substance which is not divided, therefore it is not the case that God alone is undivided.

In the second place the Philosohper II De anima says
the intellect absolutely unmixed and immaterial Aristoteles, De anima, II, XXX .
In the third place, against the first corollary is the first reasons in the opposition because some simple thing is so simple that only a single grade and punctual being corresponds to it, therefore.

In the fourth place, by the authority of the
Commentator in book 12 of the Metaphysics
who says that
all forms are existing in actuality in the first mover which are in potency in the prime matter
Averroes, XII Comment. in Metaphysica, commento 18. (Juntina VIII , 305v I)
, therefore is not in God simplicity in every form.

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first, the antecedent is denied. To the proof, the major and minor is denied. And to the proof of the minor, I say that to be necessary is repugnant to the creature not only from that which is from another, but also because it is freely contingently produced from nothing and contingently conserved.

To the second, the assumed is conceded and it is denied that it is impossible because it does not follow that the divine will changes or is changeable. Otherwise it would be able to be proved that ever future thing comes about necessarily.

To the third, the consequence is denied because then the accidents and the light produced in some manner in medium would not be able not to be. In the second place, I say that though they do not have matter, nevertheless they have their own nothingness as if matter and this suffices.

To the fourth, it is able to be said that punctual and indivisible being corresponds to it, and the consequence is denied, therefore it is not of immense perfection because at the same time it is indivisible, super simple, and immense, not having in itself formally any gradual latitude although it contains supereminently every latitude of perfection.

To the fifth, the consequent is conceded because some part of the latitude is able to be put into being, and if it is inferred, then it is able to be put into being at the same time. The consequence is denied because, just as it also does not follow that some part of that latitude is able to be put into being, therefore it is possible that some part of it be put into being, so it does not follow that some continuous part a from Socrates is able to be seen, therefore Socrates is able to see some continuous part a. Nor does it follow that some possible grade of perfection is able to be put into being, therefore it is possible that some possible grade of perfection should be put into being, thought I hold the consequent to be probable in
my principio Supra vide
against what it said before.

To the sixth, the consequence is denied because the deity does not exist in manner of a created person nor that of the divine person through the mode of individuals because, thought two human beings are some one thing which is greater than one alone, nevertheless two divine persons are not greater than one alone, as
Augustine says in VIII De Trinitate, capitulo primo Augustinus, De Trinitate, VIII, c. 1 (XXX) .

To another, the consequence is denied because the conclusion and corollary are understood about real entities and not about things
signifying in a complex way.

To another, the antecedent is denied because for this, it follows that to be necessary is not to be necessary. And to the disproof, I say that for the impossible, something follows, and as a consequence the from the negative, the affirmative follows.

To the first against the second conclusion, it is said that Damascenus does not speak about perfections that are not really in God, but about names which are predicated of God, some of which according to him are not predicated of his nature, but about those things which are concerning his nature which should not be understood with respect to the thing signified because, if a thing which is divine wisdom were not the divine nature, but something concerning his nature, it would not only be distinguished formally, but really and absolutely, which is false. But it is understood with respect to the mode of predicating because such names are predicated of God denominatively. And those things that are predicated about God with respect to the mode of predicated of God with respect to the mode of predicating do not speak about nature about, but about something concerning nature. This is the solution of Alphonsus.

To the second, in the first place it would be able to be said that divisibly or through a divisible he distances himself from an angel because he distances himself through the total perfection of all creaturea actual and possible. And the consequences is denied, therefore so are parts because this divisibility is not instrinsic in God, but extrinsic.

In the second place, by denying the consequence it would be able to be said that he distances himself indivisibly, therefore infinitely less than anything below because that which is indivisible through what it distances itself is immense because it is God.

To another, the consequence is denied. The reason is because infinite wisdom and infinite goodness in reality are something circumscribed by every reasons of the intellect. But wisdom in general and goodness in general are not thus because they are not unless some concept or being of reason. And to the proof, it is conceded because infinity does not destroy the formal reason of something, but this does not prove the intent because wisdom and goodness in general are not only predicated of infinite wisdom and goodness, but also of finite wisdom and goodness. About this see Alphonsum.

To another against the third corollary, having conceded the antecedent, the consequence is denied, for it does not follow that this thing is in diverse ways because it is possible that the proposed same signified thing is in one true and another false, nevertheless it does not follow that the thing signified is true and false.

To another, the consequent is conceded. And to the proof, because the object of one, etc., it is conceded. And when it is disproved, because God understand evil etc., it is conceded, but what is inferred does not follow.

In the second place I say that the divine will understands every evil because the divine intellect which understands is formally the divine will. Evil therefore is an object of the will, not as something willed, but as something known and understood.
In the third place this consequence would be able to be denied, the divine will and intellect are the same, therefore whatever the intellect understands, the will wills.

To another, the major is denied and the minor because it is not necessary that everything that necessitates to distinct concepts is conceptually distinct unless we wish from the use of a word. Nor also does divine perfection necessitate to the distinction of diverse acts as the argument assumes.

To the argument against the third corollary, the major is denied because divine wisdom is every perfection formally, and everything that is is better than what is absolutely not under the good intellect.

To the first authority against the the third conclusion, intelligence is a substance which is not divided. This is true with respect to parts of nature with respect to duration, which is a whole at one and the same time.

To another, it is said that the intellectu is a simple power, that is, non organic. This is the position of the Philosopher. In the second place it is said that simple in some mode is not simple absolutely because every creature in some mode is a composite subject to potentiality.

To the first reason in the opposition, it is said that, if the antecedent is understood about simplicity absolutely, then it is false. And to the proof, it is said that consequence is not valid. And if it were further inferred that the soul is not simple, therefore it has parts, the consequence is denied.

To another, it is said that forms of this type are in the first mover are indistinct in act because the creature in God is not other than the divine nature
indistinct within.
To the other arguements in the opposition, the solution is clear through what has been said.

Nunc de veritate seu proprietate Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 8, c. 1 (I, 95, ll. 4). . This distinction contains nine conclusions. First that God alone truly and properly is because his essence did not know past or future, that is not under any past or future, as other created things are.
Second conclusion: therefore he says God always was and always will be, so that it is understood that he did not begin to be nor will he cease to be.

Third conclusion: that though substantive words about diverse times are said about God, namely that he has been, will be, is and was, nevertheless they are not said about God because the that the divine being is subjected to to the past or the future with temporal motion is repugnant to God, but they are said for the purpose of denoting that God is eternity and the property of his permanence.

Fourth conclusion: the essence of God alone is properly said to be incommutable because it does not change and is not able to change. However every creature is able to be changed, but God is not neither in space nor in time nor in affection, and thus he created all creatures without any change in himself. And as a consequence, God alone properly has immortality. However every creature is mortal from its nature because its mutation is called death.

Fifth conclusion: God alone is truly or properly simple because in him there is not a diversity or different mode or multitude of parts or accidents or forms Ever creature is multiple, although a spiritual creature with respect to what is corporeal is said to be simple, nevertheless not truly simple because in such a thing there is a diversity of accidents or accidental forms, as there are in animals, humans, and angels, for nothing that is truly simple is changeable.

Sixth conclusion: that the soul with respect to the body is said to be simple because the parts are not spread through the space of place, but in each body the whole is all together and in each of its parts.

Seventh conclusion: that though God is said in many ways, namely good, just, wise, and great, nevertheless this is not on account of a diversity of accidents, but on account of a multitude of names which, though they are many and diverse, nevertheless they signify one thing, namely the divine nature.

Eight conclusion: that God is not properly called substance as if he is the subject of his goodness or of some accident, just as a bodily substance, which is called substance because it subsists and is the subject of many accidents, but God is properly and truly called essence.

Ninth conclusion: God is therefore said to be simple because he is whatever he has, with the exception that a person is said relatively to another, nevertheless one is not the other. For the Father has the Son to whom he is said relatively, and nevertheless the Father is not the Son, and the Son has the Father, and nevertheless is not the Father in whom he is truly said to himself and not to another, this is what he has. Whence God himself is one and has life and he is one life and there is not one thing that is having and another thing which is had, just as in other things where some distinction always follows.
